awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research:Virtual Sully: Autopilot with Multilevel Adaptation for Handling Large Uncertainties
awd_abstract_narration:
During normal operations an aircraft is operated by its autopilot. When the autopilot sense a dangerous condition, near or outside of  the flight envelope, the autopilot disengages itself, returning control to the pilot. Well-trained pilots typically can deal with modest out-of-envelope challenges. A pilot who can deal with a significantly compromised flight envelope is very remarkable as happened with Captain Chesley Sullenberger ("Sully") and co-pilot Jeffrey Skiles on US Airways Flight 1549 in 2009 when the aircraft struck a flock of geese just northeast of the George Washington Bridge and suddenly lost all engine power over Manhattan. The pilots glided their plane extraordinarily skillfully to a ditching in the Hudson River off Midtown Manhattan,  saving all the passengers and averting a catastrophic crash in New York City.  The National Transportation Safety Board official described it as the most successful ditching in aviation history.  This capability to operate safely despite the exceptional situation well-outside the norm is the essence of this project, Virtual Sully.

Virtual Sully technology is a development towards full pilotless autonomy, capable of identifying the failure/fault, estimating the remaining control authority, assessing the environment and planning a new feasible mission, doing path planning and executing it safely within the compromised flight envelope. This architecture replaces the traditional top-down one-way adaptation between mission planning, trajectory generation, tracking and stabilizing controller, with a two-way adaptation between mission planning, trajectory generation, and the adaptation of controller parameters to improve the stability and robustness of the control system. The following thrusts are considered: 1) monitoring and capability auditing; 2) high-assurance control with multi-level adaptation; 3) fault-tolerant architecture for unmanned autonomous systems (UAS) with real-time guarantees; 4) development of hardware-in-the loop simulation environment and flight tests using unmanned air vehicle (UAV) prototypes. Fault-tolerant computing infrastructure that can withstand high-stress situations will be integrated within flight control architecture that adapts at multiple levels. The feasibility evaluation of the missions and regenerated trajectories within UAV's remaining capabilities is pursued with real-time guarantees. The testbed is based on hardware-in-the-loop simulation for various failures, as well as extensive tests using real UAVs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overarching  goal of this project is the development of trajectory optimization algorithms for autonomous vehicles operating is cluttered, dynamic and uncertain environments.  Autonomous vehicles are the future of trasporation and their deployment and use will have with a signficant socio-economic impact. The idea and key underlying promise is that autonomous vehicles will have the capability to perform navigation tasks at scale and safely.  Despite the progress in the technologies required for safe autonomy, there is the need for decision-making architectures in autonomy that can guarantee safe operation, are interepretable (non-blackbox) and reliable.

 

The work in this award aims to address the aforementioned needs for safety in autonomy. In particular the research conducted under this award is organized into four sub-areas. The first sub-area is related to the concept of barrier states and the idea of embedded safety in trajectory optimization. The barrier states can be thought of as a mechanisms that allows trajectory optimization methods to find feasible solutions for challenging navigation tasks in dense environments. The unique feature of a barrier state is its ability to encode obstacle information in an embedded fashion within optimization. This is achieved by augmenting the state-space of the initial trajectory optimization problem formulation with a barrier state as well as a penatly function that depends on the barrier state. The aforementioned state augmentation gives trajectory optimization algorithms the control authority to quickly and intelligently find safe navigation solutions. This mechanism ensures that vehicles will be able to avoid obstacles and find collision-free paths while moving towards their prespecified target state. In our more recent papers, the work on barrier states was combined together with differential optimization and tube-based model predictive control. The resulting methodology allows self tuning and adaptation of multi-layer model predictive control architectures ensuring in this way vehicle safe navigation in uncertain and non-stationary environments

 

The second sub-area includes algorithms for safe coordination of multiple vehicles. The work in this sub-area has been performed within the framework of path integral control for multi-vehicle navigation.  The resulting algorithms exploit the structure of path integral control and its ability to scale to multi-agent use cases.

 

The third sub-area is on safe stochastic control methods using  the two frameworks of  model predictive path integral control (MPPI) and stochastic control using Forward-Backward Stochastic Differential Equations. In the first approach, model predictive control algorithms such as MPPI are combined together with covariance steering. The resulting decision-making architecture provides navigation solutions that are collision-free while operating in a receding horizon fashion. The second approach brings together concepts from control barrier states and stochastic control using forward-backward stochastic differential equations. The resulting scheme provide feasible safe trajectories under the presense of stochastic uncertainty.

 

Finally the last (fourth) sub-area uses concepts from optimal control theory to develop training algorithms for deep neural networks. The research efforts in this sub-area are dedicated to development of neural network training algorithms that rely on the first principles of feedback optimal control theory. The inspiration for this work comes from the area of autonomy in which deep neural networks are used for learning and representation. The work on understanding the training process of deep neural networks using the first principles of  optimal control theory is in the direction of developing decision-making architectures for autonomy that are interpretable and safe.


Last Modified: 07/07/2024
Modified by: Evangelos Theodorou
